article.title: Mitochondria-Targeted Human Catalase in the Mouse Longevity MCAT Model Mitigates Head-Tilt Bedrest-Induced Neuro-Inflammation in the Hippocampus
article.abstract: Microgravity (modeled by head-tilt bedrest and hind-limb unloading), experienced during prolonged spaceflight, results in neurological consequences, central nervous system (CNS) dysfunction, and potentially impairment during the performance of critical tasks.

sections.introduction: Bedrest, sedentary lifestyle, and isolation have negative effects on almost all systems of the human body, and understanding these effects has become a primary objective for enabling long-term space flights.
sections.methods: Mice were assigned to one of four experimental groups (See Supplementary Figure S1; n = 8/group unless otherwise stated) and housed in a custom caging system as previously described [48].
sections.results: Increased CD68 levels are indicative of increased microglial activation. Hippocampal sections were stained to visualize and quantify CD68 protein expression (Figure 1A).
sections.discussion: The hippocampus is crucial for learning and memory, and any alterations in this region can have detrimental consequences on CNS function.

article.insights_summary: Mitochondria-targeted human catalase in the mouse longevity MCAT model mitigates head-tilt bedrest-induced neuro-inflammation in the hippocampus.
